Docs.summary: Provides a failure handling mechanism, called a fallback, for an input character that cannot be converted to an output byte sequence. The fallback uses a user-specified replacement string instead of the original input character. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A common reason for an encoding or decoding operation to fail is if the underlying encoding class does not provide a mapping between a character and an equivalent byte sequence. For example, an <xref:System.Text.ASCIIEncoding> object cannot encode a character having a Unicode code point value that is outside the range U+0000 to U+007F. If the input character cannot be converted to an output byte sequence, a <xref:System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback> object substitutes a specified replacement string for the original input character. The conversion process encodes the replacement string and then continues to process the remainder of the original input.
The replacement string used by an <xref:System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback> object is determined by the call to its class constructor. Two options are available:
- Replacement with the default character. If you call the <xref:System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback.%23ctor> constructor, the replacement character is "?" (U+003F).
- Replacement with a string of your choice. If you call the <xref:System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback.%23ctor%28System.String%29> constructor, you provide the replacement string.
If you choose a fallback string to use with this class, make sure that the string is composed entirely of characters that can be encoded in the target encoding. Otherwise, a recursive fallback results, causing an <xref:System.ArgumentException>.
This class is one of two .NET Framework classes that implement different fallback strategies for handling encoding conversion failures. The other class is the <xref:System.Text.EncoderExceptionFallback> class, which throws an <xref:System.Text.EncoderFallbackException> when an invalid character is encountered.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `replacement` parameter initializes the replacement string that is the value of this <xref:System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback> object. You application must provide a `replacement` value that contains only characters that can be encoded in the target encoding. Otherwise, a recursive fallback results, causing an <xref:System.ArgumentException>. For example, the fallback provided for an <xref:System.Text.ASCIIEncoding> object cannot include the character "¿" (U+00BF) because that character is itself not a valid ASCII character.
As a result of this, U+FFFD, which is a good choice for a fallback string for <xref:System.Text.DecoderExceptionFallback>, is not generally a good choice for this class. Also, the null character (U+0000) cannot be used in the fallback string.

Docs.exception: contains an invalid surrogate pair. In other words, the surrogate does not consist of one high surrogate component followed by one low surrogate component.
